items.content_html:
Add the semicolon at the end of some JS statements:

The let and const declarations, require the semicolon
The var statement requires the semicolon
The do...while loop requires the semicolon
The return and throw statement requires the semicolon
items.title: Add the semicolon at the end of some JS statements

items.content_html:
Description

We made a flashcard version of the glossary to make it easier to learn/revise MDN web docs related terms. Added a link on how to use the flashcard and a link to the flashcards themselves.

Motivation

Thought it would be helpful for other people who came to view a definition in the glossary

Additional details

Done in a similar format to another project - https://github.com/OpenMined/OM-Welcome-Package/blob/master/Educational-Tools.md#flashcards

Related issues and pull requests

NA
items.title: feat: Adds link to flashcard version of the glossary

items.content_html:
Description

The code sample probably has an erroneous type="module" attribute. Removing it makes it work for me.

Motivation

Hopefully it fixes an error.

Additional details

When the attribute is present I'm getting the following messages in my console (just running firefox on the local files):

Cross-Origin Request Blocked: The Same Origin Policy disallows reading the remote resource at file:///somepath/webgl-demo.js. (Reason: CORS request not http).

Module source URI is not allowed in this document: “file:///somepath/webgl-demo.js”. index.html:6:1

Related issues and pull requests

None.
items.title: Remove type="module" attribute from script tag

items.content_html:
Description

Fixes the order of navigation links in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/Building_blocks

Motivation

According to #22618 "Selectors" should come first, then different types of selectors, and only then "Cascade and inheritance". The order of navigation was broken in the later PR and now it completely misses the different types of selectors. This PR fixes this.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Together with mdn/yari#8014 Fixes #23645
items.title: Fix order of learn css pages

items.content_html:
Description

Changes cases of CSS transform functions.

Motivation

Using differently-cased names may confuse readers, and the cases should be aligned with the spec, even though both uppercase and lowercase forms will parse.

Additional details

Transform functions in CSS Transforms Module Level 1:
https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-transforms/#transform-functions
items.title: Using conformative cases for CSS transform functions

items.content_html:
Description

Rename the page.

CSS Functional Notation => CSS value functions

Motivation

The introduction of At-rule-functions.

We have two function types:

  1. At-rule functions
  2. Value functions

Additional details

Why "value function" and not "data type functions"? Because they are defined in css-values spec.

Related issues and pull requests

Relates to: #23523 (comment)
items.title: CSS Functional Notation => CSS value functions

items.title: Clarify Block and inline boxes

items.content_html:
I could be completely wrong on this one.

I have not come across the term "formatting box" before. My understanding is the term "formatting box" is being used here to refer to the standard content (what would usually go in the "content box") with the addition of ::before and ::after elements. Given that I could not find the term "formatting box" in the spec, I thought it might be clearest to use the more common box model term "content box" as the ::before and ::after elements are rendered inside of an elements content box. It then felt best to update the link people to point people to the standard box model page.

If you are supportive of this change I can also update the ::after page

Description

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Formatting box → Content box on psuedo element pages

items.content_html:
Description

Any tabindex value suffices for an element to be focusable and thus emit keyboard events. The documentation implies that only tabindex value -1 can do that.

The page in question: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/keydown_event

Motivation

The phrase to be improved suggests that keyboard events are not emitted when the tabindex attribute of the emitting element has value other than -1. In reality, based on MDN, WHATWG, and SO, any tabindex value makes the element focusable. All focusable elements receive keyboard events, see w3c keyboard event order. To be sure, I tested that this is the case with Firefox 74 and Chrome 108.

However, the tab key and keyboard events are in temporal conflict. The tabindex value 0 and above make the element reachable by pressing the tab key. The special tabindex value -1 means that the element cannot be navigated to by pressing the tab key. The keyboard events are emitted when a key is pressed, including the tab key. Thus pressing a tab key either a) emits a keyboard event without changing focus, b) changes focus without emitting the keyboard event, or c) emits the keyboard event and then changes focus. It is unclear which of these happens. Therefore the tabindex value -1 has a special ability to avoid the conflict by not allowing tabbing to reach the keyboard target element. This conflict might have motivated the original author to limit the value to -1.

W3C keyboard event order docs mention this conflict by stating "The event target might change between different key events. For example, a keydown event for the Tab key will likely have a different event target than the keyup event on the same keystroke." This implies that the W3C recommendation is the c) outcome: emit keyboard event and then switch focus.

All in all, any tabindex value will do for element to emit keydown.

Additional details

MDN tabindex
WHATWG tabindex attribute
W3C keyboard event order
items.title: Relax tabindex value
